title: How to Get Organic CBD

steps.headline: Check for a seal labeled “organic” on the CBD package.
steps.description: Look around the package for the CBD that you want to buy and look for a seal from the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA). If you don’t see the USDA seal on the package, check near the nutritional information to see if it lists where the product was manufactured and if it’s labeled as an organic product. If you don’t see an “organic” label on the product, then it may be low-quality. The requirements for a crop or product to be organic may vary depending on your area. If you’re in the United States, you can check the USDA site to see a list of approved organic brands if you aren’t able to tell from the label. Some CBD products won’t be listed as “100% organic” because they have processed materials, but they can still be labeled “organic,” meaning that less than 5% of the ingredients are not organic.

steps.headline: Look at the ingredients to see if there are any additives.
steps.description: High-quality CBD products usually list their ingredients underneath the nutritional label on the product. Check the ingredient list and check the amounts listed for each ingredient. Make sure the ingredients include the word “organic” or have asterisks next to them, or else the product may have been processed. If you don’t see any organic labels in the ingredient list, then it may not have been harvested properly. If you don’t see any ingredients listed, then avoid the product completely since it could be low-quality. The CBD may still have an “organic” label even if up to 5% of the ingredients are not organically grown.

steps.headline: Determine if the CBD was tested by a third-party lab.
steps.description: CBD manufacturers have their products tested by laboratories to check the purity and determine the levels of contaminants. Check the package for a seal that states “third-party lab-tested” or something similar. If you don’t see a seal, look for a batch number on the back or bottom of the package. Look up the batch number online along with the name of the brand so you can see the lab results. If the CBD hasn’t been tested by a lab, then don’t buy the product since you don’t know how strong it could actually be.Tip: Some CBD products have QR codes on the package so you can easily scan them and access the lab results.

steps.headline: See if the manufacturer used ethanol or CO2 for extraction.
steps.description: Some companies use harmful chemicals, such as butane, to remove CBD from hemp plants, which could affect the overall quality of the product. Search on the package for a label that says, “extracted with CO2,” or, “extracted with ethanol,” since they produce the cleanest CBD. IF you aren’t able to find the extraction process on the package, then look up the brand online to see if it’s listed on their site. If you aren’t able to find the extraction method anywhere on the product or site, then avoid using the product.

steps.headline: Research the brand online to see if they list their growing processes.
steps.description: Look up any brands of CBD that you’re interested in buying so you can learn more about them. Click on the company’s About Us page on their site to see if they break down where they grow, which processes they follow, and how they check the product quality. Most high-quality or organic brands of CBD will have a detailed process written, but low-quality brands tend to hide the information. Check the website to see if there’s a customer support line you can contact if you have any questions.

steps.headline: Take a CBD capsule or edible for the most discreet option.
steps.description: CBD capsules have oil inside them that release as you digest them, while edibles have the oil cooked into them. Take the capsule or edible 1–2 hours before you want to start feeling the effects of the CBD. You should start feeling more relaxed and less anxious within 30 minutes to 2 hours, and the effects usually last for 3–4 hours. You can many different kinds of CBD edibles, such as chocolates, gummies, mints, peanut butter, and honey. CBD capsules and edibles tend to last longer than other delivery methods.Warning: Only take the recommended dose of CBD until you get used to how it affects your body. While it may only take a single dose for you, it may take another person a higher dose to feel the same way.

steps.headline: Use topical CBD to treat pain in a localized area.
steps.description: If you feel pain or have inflammation on a certain part of your body, you can apply a topical CBD product directly to it. Put a coin-sized amount of the CBD topical on your hand and rub it into your skin where you feel the most pain. Work the topical in until it’s clear so it can absorb completely into the area. The topical will start working within about 15 minutes and last for around 2 hours. Don’t consume topical CBD products since they could contain other lotions or oils that aren’t safe to eat.

steps.headline: Choose a CBD tincture if you want to add it to your own food or drinks.
steps.description: Get a bottle of flavorless CBD tincture and fill the dropper up to the fill line. Drop the CBD into your drink or cooked food and mix it in thoroughly. Eat or drink as you normally would and wait for about 30–60 minutes for the CBD to take effect. You should feel the effects for about 2–3 hours. You can also hold a dose of CBD tincture under your tongue for up to 5 minutes so it absorbs into your body better. You can also buy flavored CBD tinctures if you want.

steps.headline: Pick a CBD vaporizer to feel the effects quickly.
steps.description: Look for a standalone CBD vaporizer or get a cartridge that screws onto a universal battery. Turn on the vaporizer and hold the button down while you inhale the vapor deep into your lungs. Hold the vapor in your lungs as long as you can before exhaling. You should feel the effects of the CBD within about 5 minutes, and they usually last 90–120 minutes. CBD vaporizers may cause chest pain or dry mouth. The effects of vaporizers on your lungs are still being researched, so use them at your own risk.

steps.headline: Go to a dispensary or CBD specialty store if you want it immediately.
steps.description: If you live in an area that has legalized marijuana, contact your nearest dispensary to see if they also carry CBD products. Ask them which brands and products they offer so you can research them online before you buy them. If you live somewhere that doesn’t allow marijuana, you may still be able to find stores that primarily sell CBD products. Check your local store listings to find out what’s in your area. You usually need to be over 18 or 21 to enter a dispensary depending on where you live. CBD is still illegal in some areas, so it may not be available for you. You can get medicinal or medical CBD products.

steps.headline: Use a cannabis delivery service for a convenient option.
steps.description: Check online to see if there are cannabis delivery services that operate in your area. Select a CBD product from the menu online and research it to make sure it’s of high quality before adding it to your cart. Pay for the order using a debit or credit card and wait until the delivery driver arrives with your CBD. Cannabis delivery services are limited to areas where marijuana has been legalized, but they may expand to other areas in the future. You usually need to be 21 and have a valid ID to use a delivery service. Tip your driver when they deliver your CBD.

steps.headline: Order CBD products directly from the brand’s website if you can’t find it elsewhere.
steps.description: Look up the brand that you want to buy and find the products on the site’s Store page. Add the products to your cart before providing your payment and delivery information. Once you receive the product from the site, make sure it’s still sealed properly and everything on the package looks legitimate. If it doesn’t, then you can return it and request a refund. If the brand doesn’t have a Store page on their website, then you may have to find their products at a dispensary or physical storefront.Warning: Don’t buy CBD from websites that don’t list clear product details or don’t feel legitimate since you could be scammed or receive a low-quality product.
